content.overview: This guideline covers the assessment and management of acute respiratory infections in resource-limited settings.
assessment: Assess for danger signs: inability to drink, severe chest indrawing, stridor in calm child
Assess for chest indrawing and auscultate if possible
management: Mild: Home treatment with supportive care
Severe: Refer to hospital if possible, start antibiotics before transfer
content.followUp: Follow up in 2 days if not improving, immediately if worsening

content.overview: This guideline covers the assessment and management of acute diarrhea, focusing on preventing dehydration in resource-limited settings.
assessment: Assess for dehydration: sunken eyes, skin pinch, decreased urination
Check for blood in stool, fever, duration of symptoms
Assess for malnutrition which increases risk
management: Rehydration: ORS for mild to moderate dehydration
Zinc supplementation for 10-14 days for all children with diarrhea
Antibiotics only if bloody diarrhea or suspected cholera
redFlags: Severe dehydration (lethargy, very dry mouth, very sunken eyes)
content.followUp: Return immediately if unable to drink, persistent vomiting, or signs of dehydration worsen

content.overview: This guideline covers the diagnosis and management of malaria in resource-limited settings, with focus on high-risk groups.
assessment: Clinical suspicion: fever, headache, body aches, fatigue
Confirm diagnosis with RDT (Rapid Diagnostic Test) if available
Assess for severe malaria: altered consciousness, respiratory distress, severe anemia, jaundice

severe: IM artesunate if available, or IM artemether
If referral will be delayed >6 hours, give first dose of antimalarial before transfer
Manage complications: hypoglycemia, seizures, anemia as resources allow
prevention: Intermittent preventive treatment for pregnant women
Seasonal malaria chemoprevention for children where applicable

content.followUp: Return for reassessment if fever persists after 2 days of treatment

content.overview: Simplified guideline for hypertension management in resource-limited settings with focus on essential medications and monitoring.
diagnosis: BP ≥140/90 mmHg on at least two separate occasions
Check for target organ damage if possible: fundoscopy, urine dipstick for protein
Basic risk assessment: smoking, diabetes, age, previous cardiovascular events

riskStratification.highRisk: ≥3 risk factors, BP ≥180/110, or established cardiovascular disease, diabetes, or renal disease

management: Lifestyle modifications for all patients: salt reduction, physical activity, healthy diet, smoking cessation
First-line medications: thiazide diuretic, calcium channel blocker, or ACE inhibitor based on availability
Start with single drug and low dose, titrate upward if needed
Two-drug combination for BP ≥160/100 or high-risk patients
For severe hypertension (≥180/110): immediate treatment and consider referral if available
monitoring: BP check every 1-3 months until target reached, then every 3-6 months
Basic lab tests if available: creatinine, potassium, glucose yearly
Target BP <140/90 mmHg for most patients, <130/80 for high-risk patients
content.followUp: Regular follow-up essential for medication adjustment and adherence support

content.overview: Essential antenatal care and delivery guidelines for resource-limited settings to reduce maternal and perinatal mortality.

scheduling: First visit: Before 12 weeks if possible
Minimum 4 visits: <12 weeks, 24-28 weeks, 32 weeks, 36 weeks
essentialAssessments: Fetal heart rate auscultation after 20 weeks
Hemoglobin testing at least once (first visit and 36 weeks if possible)
Urine dipstick for protein if available, especially with hypertension
HIV and syphilis testing at first visit
preventiveInterventions: Intermittent preventive treatment for malaria in endemic areas
Deworming after first trimester in endemic areas

dangerSigns: Fever and too weak to get out of bed

preparations: Clean delivery kit: soap, clean blade, cord ties, clean cloths
monitoringLabor: Monitor fetal heart rate every 30 minutes in first stage, every 5 minutes in second stage
postpartumCare: Monitor for bleeding in first 24 hours
Ensure breastfeeding initiated within first hour
Check mother and newborn before discharge

emergencyReferralCriteria: Obstructed labor: no progress for >4 hours in active phase
Pre-eclampsia/eclampsia: BP ≥140/90 with proteinuria or symptoms
Fetal distress: heart rate <120 or >160 bpm
Malpresentation (transverse lie, breech if provider not skilled)
content.followUp: Postnatal visit within 48 hours, at 7 days, and at 6 weeks for mother and baby
